pr_title: Allows deep linking to open files

timeline.bodyText: I'm not exactly sure how this extra is set, but rewriting it before handling does not feel right. Also, I do not understand why we use last path segment as file id - is it the same thing?
timeline.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText: It's set from the Talk app at the moment when clicking on a shared file. The author of this PR seems to take advantage of this by rewriting it to the last segment of "nc://directlink/f/{fileID}" which would pretty much be the file id. Now, the issue is that the currently proposed nc:// syntax doesn't allow switching accounts if needed, so that should be fixed.
replies.author: mario
EvansJahja

replies.bodyText:
There are 2 problems here:

KEY_FILE_ID is re-used with 2 types of values, which complicates handling
it doesn't handle user

I believe that the ideal solution woild be to change the contract/interface and don't re-use extra keys with different arugment formats. Since both apps are already on-line this might not be the most practical appraoch, but since the URI needs a change, maybe there is a window of opportunity for this and we could introduce dedicated extra key for passing URIs, such as KEY_FILE_URI or similar?

@mario I think we can pass the username in the URI, and then when we can do
Account newAccount = getUserAccountManager().getAccountByName({username})


Please be aware that we are (slowly) departing from platfrm account managment API in favour of our own User abstraction, therefore it would be best if we could use UserAccountManager.getUser (or similar) API instead.
replies.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText:
An alternative would be to make the username mandatory in forms like
"nc://directlink/u/{username}/f/{fileID}", or maybe even "nc://directlink/{username}/f/{fileID}"

I believe URI specification has support for users, so: nc://user@authority/path should be ok. This is one thing.
Another one is directlink -  generally it is expected (by code reader) that the authority part tells which app is handling it. So a link looking more or less like  nc://user@${authority}/file/${file_id} would match the expected convention better.
For all practical purposes, the authority part of the URI is same thing as in content provider and usually denotes application package name.
We could - at some point in time - want to implement direct links in other Nextcloud apps, such as Talk (send file from files app to talk) or in News. In such case, you'll need to come up with "creative" URI schemes to distinguish between apps.
@mario is this URI still in development phase? If so, could we consider making some alterations before it's stable, relleased and untouchable?
replies.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText: com.nextcloud.client is a generalized (no flavour suffix) form of app package for the files app, btw. We might be willing to have deep links into com.nextcloud.talk or com.nextcloud.news in the future as well.
replies.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText:
handleOpenFileViaIntent already handles the case where account is not set, but we should definitely have it in the URI. I'm not sure authority is needed as the prefix actually decides which app(s) can open an URI, but feel free to convince me otherwise @ezaquarii. Keep in mind that user should be in form of "userId@server" so with your suggestion it would be:
"nc://userId@server/file/${file_id}"
As for Talk @ezaquariil, since both Files and Talk are Android app I take advantage of an Intent with the required parameters
replies.author: mario

timeline.bodyText: Not sure what is going on here. If you want to check if extra value is null, check usgin == operator. Using string formatting to compare string representation of objects is not how we do this in Java, which is strongly typed and don't need this kind of hacks, contrary to JavaScript.
timeline.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText: @ezaquarii Okay, I will do that. The String fileId = String.valueOf(intent.getStringExtra(KEY_FILE_ID)); part confuses me to, as I did not write it. I only move the expression upwards.
replies.author: EvansJahja

replies.bodyText: @tobiasKaminsky can you comment on this?
replies.author: AndyScherzinger

replies.bodyText: @Charon77 Thanks. We try to do cleanups whenever possible.
replies.author: ezaquarii

timeline.author: ezaquarii

timeline.bodyText: Please properly validate list size before using it. Exceptions are not meant to be used as a flow control mechanism.
timeline.author: ezaquarii

timeline.bodyText: @rullzer do you know if the directLink always contains "index.php" or can there be setups where no index.php is used?
timeline.author: tobiasKaminsky

replies.bodyText: highly depends on rewrite rules I guess
replies.author: AndyScherzinger

replies.bodyText: The URL with index.php should always work, we use that in some other places where we don't know about the actual rewriting settings as a save fallback.
replies.author: juliushaertl

replies.bodyText:
But it is the other way around:
We want to check for every share link, but they are created by server and can be either
http://cloud.com/index.php/f/123 or
http://cloud.com//f/123
or?
So we cannot rely on "/index.php/f/.*" pattern?
replies.author: tobiasKaminsky

replies.bodyText:
We also have to think about subdirectories, so full potential list would be:
http://cloud.com/index.php/f/123
http://cloud.com//f/123
http://cloud.com/subfolder/index.php/f/123
http://cloud.com/subfolder/f/123
(subdomains should not be affected)
replies.author: tobiasKaminsky

replies.bodyText:
In my testing have the internal links always contained "/index.php/f/" no matter if you have pretty urls enabled or not. So we should can reliably rely on this pattern I would say.
But yes, subdomains also should considered here, too.
That was also the reason why I suggested to use the hostdomain here, so everything between "http://" or "https://" and "/index.php/f/"
can't we check if the link contains "/index.php/f/" at all? So no matter at which place?
Also shouldn*t the username then also contain this path, that wen can check against, so e.g. "user@cloud.com/subfolder"?
replies.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText: @Charon77 Is this review thread already solved?
replies.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText: not so sure what's going on here. can you give a test case?
replies.author: EvansJahja

replies.bodyText:
@tobiasKaminsky has provided some (but not all are possible afaik)
Correct ones are e.g.:
http://cloud.com/index.php/f/123
But also:
http://cloud.com/subfolder/index.php/f/123
So would this PR in the current state also work with links like the second one? Because it is actually possible to install Nextcloud like this (in a subfolder) which would create such links.
So the "/index.php/f/" isn't always at the same position in the link. (But I don't know how users would look like then. But theoratically they shoud reflect the subfolder, too)
replies.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText: Yes it would.
replies.author: mario

replies.bodyText: Nice! And btw: is there a possibility to test this PR? (The apk-creation seems to have failed...)
replies.author: szaimen
EvansJahja

replies.bodyText:
@Charon77 Thanks for linking me, I've tried the app and it works nicely!
But there seems to be a bug:
now all subdomains work, but also other domains, that are not the same like the domain, the user is from:
So if my user is admin@localhost and test@localhost, bot have access to the file, then links like https://localhost/index.php/f/39503 work but also e.g. https://cloud.com/index.php/f/35903 and https://localhost/hdjhd/index.php/f/39503 work and I think this shouldn't be the case here. The only different to the first localhost link is, that it opens the file directly with the current account without asking which account you want to use when clicking in that link.
But I think it should say, that the link isn't working, and/or open that link directly in the Browser because no matching account was found...
So I would say, it ahould really depend on the host matching the account and not if the file-id was found with any account.
replies.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText:
Can you test this out:
This no longer defaults to current user when account is not found, and instead says that the account is not found. Opening the link in browser might be a bit tricky.
https://github.com/Charon77/android/releases/tag/aff6be0e
replies.author: EvansJahja

replies.bodyText:
@Charon77 I would like to, but I cannot install the latest apk you have linked.
Maybe one of those links can help you achieving the opening in the browser if no account was found?
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2201917/how-can-i-open-a-url-in-androids-web-browser-from-my-application
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3004515/sending-an-intent-to-browser-to-open-specific-url
Maybe it should then say to the user, that "No Account matching the URL was found, opening the link in the browser..."  (Or something like that)
And directly open the link in the browser afterwards.
replies.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText:
@szaimen Try the updated apk:
https://github.com/Charon77/android/releases/tag/aff6be0e
the file is aff6be0e_2.apk
Currently, if no matching user is found, it will say Associated user is not found.
There will be problems by opening the link in the browser (and kind of defeats the purpose of  the app). I think the case when no account matches the URL should be a separate issue.
replies.author: EvansJahja

replies.bodyText:
@Charon77 I don't think that it would defeat the purpose of the app. Because if no user is found, it is probably not a link from your Nextcloud that you have clicked on and/or no Nextcloud at all.
For those cases it would make much sense if the app would be able to open the link in the browser directly.
And please tell me which problems do you see for opening the link directly in the browser (if no account was found). Maybe they have a good foundation but I have to know them. Otherwise we cannot discuss them.
I will try the updated apk later on.
replies.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText:
First of all, I have not tried the link you suggested but I have read them.
Here's a scenario I think of where it's problematic. If a user opens a "potentially nextcloud URL", the user would be presented with choices: Would you like to open the URL in your browser, or nextcloud? And user would click "Always" or "Just once". Let's assume the user clicks nextcloud, and click "Always". Then, we realize that the URL is not a Nextcoud URL. However, since the Nextcloud app is set to perform Intent.ACTION_VIEW on said URL, it will relaunch the same activity, and says that there's no account, and the whole thing will run forever.
replies.author: EvansJahja

replies.bodyText:
@Charon77 Thanks for sharing your thoughts!
I can understand your concerns, but the idea was to prevent the loop from happening through launching directly a browser activity. I don't know if it works, but it theoratically should.
IMO, launching the browser directly through the browser-activity would be the best UX, in the case, that no matching account was found, but I could also imagine a UI which is asking the user if you want to continue launching the link in the browser. Then you could click on no or yes.
BTW: I've tested the app and it works really well now! Only the opening in the browser is missing imho ;)
replies.author: szaimen
szaimen

timeline.bodyText:
Maybe add an additional android:scheme="https" here?
Then it works with https links, too.
timeline.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText: Yup, that's what needs doing.
replies.author: mario

timeline.bodyText:
We have discussed the format of account name extensively when trying to formalize account ID:
#5006
AFAIR, the conclusion was that we cannot rely on this format, but maybe we should take a step back and look at it again.
@tobiasKaminsky @mario @AndyScherzinger
timeline.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText: I thought we can rely on the format as in @, no?
replies.author: AndyScherzinger

replies.bodyText:
Actually I am also not quite sure. This is from the docs:

But for now I would say it is good enough?
replies.author: szaimen

replies.bodyText: Well, with this info we would have to look for the last @ character to split the string I guess.
replies.author: AndyScherzinger

replies.bodyText: Solved in bcd277f
replies.author: EvansJahja

replies.bodyText:
Sorry for seeing this too late, but we have:
https://github.com/nextcloud/android-library/blob/master/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/lib/common/accounts/AccountUtils.java#L101
This should be enough and we stay consistent with our other account handling.
replies.author: tobiasKaminsky

replies.bodyText:
Better is to use: UserAccountManager, as this is our own implementation and we try to get rid of AccountManager.
From userAccountManager you can get User, which then has Server and this has Uri, which is also the baseUrl.
replies.author: tobiasKaminsky

timeline.bodyText: Please do not use platform API. We try to get rid of it. We have our own abstraction of account: UserAccountManager and User.
timeline.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText: 6d4ec4e
replies.author: EvansJahja

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure what we do here.
Is there any reason why we try to build the URL ourselves and then use getBaseUrlForAccount only to see if we built it correctly?
timeline.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText:
given direct link from the intent in forms of
http://example.com:567/index.php/f/123
I'd like to extract the
http://example.com:567
part.
queryBaseUrl is from intent. getBaseUrlforAccount is from the account in getAccounts()
replies.author: EvansJahja

timeline.bodyText: Please use User instead of Account.
timeline.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText:
Not so sure why, but alright
04fc793
replies.author: EvansJahja

replies.bodyText: Because we do this: https://github.com/nextcloud/android/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#custom-platform-apis
replies.author: ezaquarii

replies.bodyText: Ah, my bad. Thanks for pointing out
replies.author: EvansJahja
